items.title: Week 2023-46
items.content_html:
This week began with me literally printing documents at midnight. I found myself in the kitchen, searching for an outlet to charge our printer for printing all the paperwork to renew tinyScientist’s passport.

Curiously, our Canon Printer flashes a green light when its battery is low and needs charging, and blinks red while recharging. This is counterintuitive to me – I would have expected a blinking red light to signal the need for recharging. This design choice remains a mystery.

Monday was a day off for me, as we had appointments with tinyScientist’s doctors in preparation for his upcoming surgery. Thankfully, everything is in order; we just have to wait a few more weeks. Soon, this will all be in the past.

I was looking for solo pen-and-paper RPG games, and found a game called Four Against Darkness. Further research led me to another solo system, D100 Dungeon. While not strictly RPGs, they are close enough and serve my purpose well. I’ve finished the game book for Four Against Darkness and am about to start on the D100 Dungeon book. Then I’ll decide which one I’m gonna invest my time.

I’ve also started reading a book by Brazilian cartoonist Mauricio Ricardo, Missioni: Uma História sobre Brasileiros em Guerra. I expect to finish it either today or tomorrow. It’s a good book and a good summary of how things work in Brazil.

A new hobby of mine is creating images with DALL-E 3. I’ve been updating the cover art for my Apple Music playlists using the tool, based on the songs in each playlist. The Music app looks much nicer now!

However, following the latest major ChatGPT update, I feel that DALL-E 3’s performance has slightly deteriorated, along with the system’s overall stability. In recent days, I’ve encountered numerous errors and slowdowns while generating images.

Lastly, I’ve made the decision this week to transfer my notes from Obsidian to Bear. This isn’t my first time switching between these platforms, and I suspect I might revert to Obsidian again. More to come.

items.title: Bear and Obsidian
items.content_html:
I was planning to create a long and detailed list of pros and cons to decide between Bear and Obsidian. However, I realized that lists can be easily skewed to favor a particular outcome. For example, if comparing an iPhone with a potato, we could ask which one stays on the kitchen counter longer without needing a charge, right?

Obsidian is impressive. I can use it across all my devices, whether personal or for work, and it’s easily enhanced with third-party plugins. This includes a plugin I created for publishing posts and pages directly to Micro.blog. However, Obsidian has its downsides. It’s not a native app, which affects its aesthetics and functionality, especially on mobile devices. Additionally, its synchronization service can be quite expensive.

Bear, conversely, is simple and intuitive. It integrates seamlessly with the Apple ecosystem, which suits me fine. However, its synchronization is limited to devices under the same iCloud account, which is problematic since I use different accounts for personal and work purposes. Bear does require a subscription for synchronization, but it’s much more affordable compared to Obsidian.

Feature-wise, both are excellent. They are robust markdown editors, support linking between notes, code blocks with syntax highlighting, and allow inline images, which is all I really need.

So, my choice boils down to the one that precisely meets my needs without overcomplicating things or offering an overwhelming array of customization options. After all, sometimes less is more. Plus, it doesn’t cost nearly 100 EUR/year just to host a few text files.

PS: The image which illustrates this post was generated using DALL-E 3.

items.title: Week 2023-45
items.content_html:
I visited the office three times this week — on Tuesday, Thursday, and Friday. It was a week filled with meetings and a Leadership workshop focusing on one-on-one meetings. On Friday afternoon, several of us gathered for our Learning Time, and in the evening, scientist, tinyScientist, and I enjoyed dinner with friends.

Starting this weekend, we are officially practicing social distancing as tinyScientist’s second surgery is on the horizon.

items.title: Week 2023-44
items.content_html:
Last weekend I started feeling unwell. By Sunday night, my condition had worsened significantly. As result, I took sick leave on Monday, Tuesday, and also on Wednesday. By Thursday, I managed to return to work, though I had not fully recovered.

On Friday, feeling better and back to full health, I headed to the office. It was quieter than usual since most of my colleagues prefer to work from home at the end of the week. However, in my team, we have time dedicated to learning on Fridays, and I find the office to be an ideal environment for this.

Out of caution, I took several COVID tests during the week, all of which thankfully returned negative. This means I have managed to stay COVID-free after all these years.

On a brighter note, I released a new version of Micro.publish, which now enables users to publish and update pages from Obsidian to Micro.blog directly. My reliance on Obsidian for writing and frequent updates to Micro.blog made it a natural progression to add this feature. The updated plugin was rolled out to all users on Tuesday.

The following day, Manton rolled out an update to the Micro.blog’s API that allows developers to choose whether a page should be included in the blog’s navigation. From the UX perspective this is great, so on Wednesday, I released Micro.publish 2.2.0, featuring this latest addition.

After introducing page support to Micro.publish, I manually imported all the pages I had into Obsidian. I can now use Obsidian as the primary platform for editing my mini Digital Garden. With just a few clicks, any changes I make go live instantly.

Last Sunday, a group from Glass went on a photowalk to capture some beautiful street photography, marking their first official meetup. Unfortunately, I had to miss this event thanks to the cold, which was quite disappointing.

In between everything, I managed to squeeze in a visit to the Apple Store for an in-store trade-in. I erased all data from my old iPhone 13 Pro Max and an iPad that I no longer used and returned them over to Apple. As a result, I got my new iPhone without having to pay anything.

However, the transition wasn’t entirely seamless. In setting up my new iPhone, I was unexpectedly locked out of my banking app. My bank flagged the new device setup at 3am as suspicious, and I had to visit a physical branch to resolve the issue. Although this likely could have been handled over the phone, I used the opportunity to take care of some other banking tasks I had been delaying.

To my surprise and delight, the coffee shop next to my bank branch had reopened. I had a great flat white and a fantastic lemon poppy seed muffin — a small treat that added a sweet note to my day.

Lastly, I revisited a long-paused pastime in entertainment; I finally finished watching The Mentalist, a TV show I began over a decade ago but never saw through to the end. The series was put on hold when I moved between countries, and for years, the show remained unfinished. Returning to it after such a long time was truly gratifying. The show is exceptional, and completing it brought a satisfying sense of closure to a chapter that had remained open for far too long.

All things considered, despite some setbacks, it was a good week.

items.title: Micro.publish 2.2.0
items.content_html:
A couple of days ago, I released Micro.publish version 2.1.0, which introduced the ability to publish and update pages on Micro.blog.

However, there was a limitation. Pages created using the Micropub API would invariably be added to the blog’s navigation, which, in most Micro.blog themes, appears as a bar at the top of the page.

Since its release, Manton has updated the Micropub API to accept a new parameter, mp-navigation. This addition allows developers to control whether a page should be included in the navigation bar.

With Micro.publish 2.2.0, a fresh option is now available in the plugin settings. Users can determine the default setting for including new pages in the blog navigation.

When publishing a new page, users have the opportunity to override this default setting for the specific page they are working on.

I cannot express enough gratitude to Manton for the API change. It significantly enhances the Micro.publish experience for all the users who regularly use the plugin.
items.content_text:
A couple of days ago, I released [Micro.publish version 2.1.0](https://otavio.cc/2023/10/31/micropublish.html), which introduced the ability to publish and update pages on Micro.blog.

However, there was a limitation. Pages created using the Micropub API would invariably be added to the blog's navigation, which, in most Micro.blog themes, appears as a bar at the top of the page.

Since its release, [Manton](https://manton.org) has updated the Micropub API to accept a new parameter, `mp-navigation`. This addition allows developers to control whether a page should be included in the navigation bar.

With Micro.publish 2.2.0, a fresh option is now available in the plugin settings. Users can determine the default setting for including new pages in the blog navigation.

![Settings for page navigation](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/settings-page-navigation.png)

When publishing a new page, users have the opportunity to override this default setting for the specific page they are working on.

![Override option for page navigation](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/override-page-navigation.png)

I cannot express enough gratitude to Manton for the API change. It significantly enhances the Micro.publish experience for all the users who regularly use the plugin.

items.title: Micro.publish 2.1.0
items.content_html:
As I mentioned in my previous weekly note, I’ve been working on a new Micro.publish feature. This feature enables users to publish Pages directly to Micro.blog and also provides the capability to update pages previously published using version 2.1.0 or later.

To provide clarity and coherence, I’ve renamed the existing Obsidian commands. Now, to publish and update a post, users can use the following command in Obsidian’s Command Palette:

  • Micro.publish: Publish Post to Micro.blog

And, for publishing and updating a page, the command is:

  • Micro.publish: Publish Page to Micro.blog

Due to certain Micropub limitations, it’s currently impossible to prevent new pages from appearing in the blog’s navigation bar by default. Thus, after publishing a new page, should a user wish to exclude the page from the navigation bar, they would need to manually visit their ‘Pages’ section in Micro.blog and remove it from the navigation bar. Fortunately, once removed, subsequent updates to the page from Obsidian won’t add the link back to the navigation bar.

From a technical standpoint, there is a workaround. However, it would require the use of outdated APIs. I’m hesitant to combine two distinct technologies unless it becomes a issue for many users.

The update rolls out to all users tomorrow.

P.S. The image in this post was generate using DALL-E 3. I wish I could draw like this.
items.content_text:

To provide clarity and coherence, I've renamed the existing Obsidian commands. Now, to publish and update a post, users can use the following command in Obsidian's Command Palette:

- *Micro.publish: Publish Post to Micro.blog*

And, for publishing and updating a page, the command is:

- *Micro.publish: Publish Page to Micro.blog*

Due to certain [Micropub](https://book.micro.blog/micropub/) limitations, it's currently impossible to prevent new pages from appearing in the blog's navigation bar by default. Thus, after publishing a new page, should a user wish to exclude the page from the navigation bar, they would need to manually visit their 'Pages' section in Micro.blog and remove it from the navigation bar. Fortunately, once removed, subsequent updates to the page from Obsidian won't add the link back to the navigation bar.

From a technical standpoint, there is a workaround. However, it would require the use of outdated APIs. I'm hesitant to combine two distinct technologies unless it becomes a issue for many users.

The update rolls out to all users tomorrow.

P.S. The image in this post was generate using [DALL-E 3](https://openai.com/dall-e-3). I wish I could draw like this.

items.title: Week 2023-43
items.content_html:
Work

I began the week by heading to the office. As we were initiating a new Sprint, my schedule was filled with an array of sessions, ranging from retrospectives to daily meetings, and from pre-planning to planning sessions. Additionally, I had several one-on-one meetings.

Mondays at the office are always delightful. The kitchen brims with fresh croissants, sandwiches, and a huge variety of tempting pastries.

By Friday, I found myself back at the office. Given our dedicated Learning Time on Fridays, it’s an ideal day to be there in person, facilitating activities such as pair programming or collaborative tasks with colleagues. That afternoon, three of us collaborated in a meeting room, focusing on modularizing a particular feature.

The Office Manager from our German branch was in the midst of giving our workspace a Halloween facelift. I particularly loved how she swapped out our Unicorn for a festive-themed one. A charming touch.

Hacking

Last week, I published a Micro.blog plugin called “Reply on Mastodon.” Although I’m not using it – as posts on my Mastodon account are programmed to auto-delete after a month – I’ve been buoyed by the positive feedback from those who’ve adopted the plugin. While I ensure all my content is preserved on my blog, my Mastodon operates differently.

Since I rely on Obsidian for my writing and publish posts and pages to Micro.blog, I’ve embarked on developing a new Micro.publish feature. This will enable users to upload pages directly from the editor. I’m optimistic about rolling out this feature by next Tuesday or Wednesday, contingent upon the time I can allocate.

New iPhone

This Wednesday, for a fleeting moment, Apple stocked the iPhone I had wanted. However, due to my back-to-back meetings, I missed the chance to snag it. By the time I was free to visit the store, the model was out of stock.

Can you believe the same happened on Thursday?

However, luck was on my side on Saturday morning. While waiting at the bakery, I impulsively checked the Apple Store app. To my astonishment, the exact model – in terms of color and capacity – was available. Within a mere 30 seconds, I managed to purchase both bread and a new iPhone.

EDC

Last but not least, I recently received my much-anticipated order from JetPens: the Tactile Turn Bolt Action Pen (Titanium). While I have a fondness for fountain pens, when it comes to everyday carry, this pen is unrivaled.
items.content_text:
## Work

I began the week by heading to the office. As we were initiating a new [Sprint](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scrum_(software_development)#Sprint), my schedule was filled with an array of sessions, ranging from retrospectives to daily meetings, and from pre-planning to planning sessions. Additionally, I had several one-on-one meetings.

Mondays at the office are always delightful. The kitchen brims with fresh croissants, sandwiches, and a huge variety of tempting pastries.

By Friday, I found myself back at the office. Given our dedicated Learning Time on Fridays, it's an ideal day to be there in person, facilitating activities such as pair programming or collaborative tasks with colleagues. That afternoon, three of us collaborated in a meeting room, focusing on modularizing a particular feature.

The Office Manager from our German branch was in the midst of giving our workspace a Halloween facelift. I particularly loved how she swapped out our [Unicorn](https://otavio.cc/2022/10/14/went-to-the.html) for a festive-themed one. A charming touch.

![Halloween Unicorn](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/img-99636655-vintagekodak.jpeg)

## Hacking

Last week, I published a [Micro.blog](https://micro.blog/) plugin called "Reply on Mastodon." Although I'm not using it – as posts on my Mastodon account are programmed to auto-delete after a month – I've been buoyed by the positive feedback from those who've adopted the plugin. While I ensure all my content is preserved on my blog, my Mastodon operates differently.

Since I rely on Obsidian for my writing and publish posts and pages to Micro.blog, I've embarked on developing a new [Micro.publish](https://otavio.cc/micropublish/) feature. This will enable users to upload pages directly from the editor. I'm optimistic about rolling out this feature by next Tuesday or Wednesday, contingent upon the time I can allocate.

## New iPhone

This Wednesday, for a fleeting moment, Apple stocked the iPhone [I had wanted](https://otavio.cc/2023/10/14/week.html). However, due to my back-to-back meetings, I missed the chance to snag it. By the time I was free to visit the store, the model was out of stock.

Can you believe the same happened on Thursday?

However, luck was on my side on Saturday morning. While waiting at the bakery, I impulsively checked the Apple Store app. To my astonishment, the exact model – in terms of color and capacity – was available. Within a mere 30 seconds, I managed to purchase both bread and a new iPhone.

## EDC

Last but not least, I recently received my much-anticipated order from JetPens: the [Tactile Turn Bolt Action Pen (Titanium)](https://www.jetpens.com/Tactile-Turn-Bolt-Action-Pen-Titanium/pd/24327). While I have a fondness for fountain pens, when it comes to everyday carry, this pen is unrivaled.

items.title: Week 2023-42
items.content_html:
One of the advantages of a hybrid working model is the flexibility to work from home whenever I choose. However, the downside is that, when I opt to stay at home, I sometimes forget to leave the house for days. In fact, this week, the first time I stepped outside was on Thursday. On Friday, I decided to work from the office to get some fresh air, interact with people, and have lunch at a restaurant.

For my omg.lol client for macOS and iOS, I had plans to complete the migration from the ObservableObject protocol to Apple’s new Observation framework introduced earlier this year, but unfortunately, I couldn’t find the time for it. My Xcode has been open on my personal computer for over a week, with the same files still awaiting edits.

There were no new features implemented on Micro.publish either. The only Micro.publish related change during the week was the addition of a link in my blog’s navigation bar at the top of the page.

Nevertheless, I did manage to carve out some time to create a plugin for a feature that the Micro.blog community had been discussing, called Reply on Mastodon. This plugin generates a link that directs readers to the cross-post on Mastodon, allowing them to engage in conversations and reply.

The implementation was straightforward, but it required some adjustments on the Micro.blog side to function correctly. Essentially, the plugin needs cross-post information to add the link to the page. Naturally, you can’t have the cross-post information before assembling the post to publish. Fortunately, Manton made the necessary changes on the Micro.blog side to ensure the plugin works as expected.

In addition to this, I submitted a Pull Request to integrate Reply on Mastodon directly into Tiny Theme. Matt Langford reviewed and released a new version of the theme on either Friday or Saturday (I can’t recall the exact day). With this integration, users can effortlessly install the Reply on Mastodon plugin on their blogs, eliminating the need for complex integration and customization.

Sunday is reserved to Super Mario Bros. Wonder.
items.content_text:
One of the advantages of a hybrid working model is the flexibility to work from home whenever I choose. However, the downside is that, when I opt to stay at home, I sometimes forget to leave the house for days. In fact, this week, the first time I stepped outside was on Thursday. On Friday, I decided to work from the office to get some fresh air, interact with people, and have lunch at a restaurant.

![Photo of a hot stone pot Bibimbap, a Korean rice dish](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/img-8608-edited-edited.jpg)

For my [omg.lol](https://omg.lol) client for macOS and iOS, I had plans to complete the migration from the `ObservableObject` protocol to Apple's new Observation framework introduced earlier this year, but unfortunately, I couldn't find the time for it. My Xcode has been open on my personal computer for over a week, with the same files still awaiting edits.

There were no new features implemented on [Micro.publish](https://otavio.cc/micropublish/) either. The only Micro.publish related change during the week was the addition of a link in my blog's navigation bar at the top of the page.

Nevertheless, I did manage to carve out some time to create a plugin for a feature that the [Micro.blog](https://micro.blog) community had been discussing, called [Reply on Mastodon](https://micro.blog/account/plugins/view/111). This plugin generates a link that directs readers to the cross-post on Mastodon, allowing them to engage in conversations and reply.

The implementation was straightforward, but it required some adjustments on the Micro.blog side to function correctly. Essentially, the plugin needs cross-post information to add the link to the page. Naturally, you can't have the cross-post information before assembling the post to publish. Fortunately, Manton made the necessary changes on the Micro.blog side to ensure the plugin works as expected.

In addition to this, I submitted a Pull Request to integrate *Reply on Mastodon* directly into [Tiny Theme](https://github.com/MattSLangford/Tiny-Theme-for-Micro.blog). [Matt Langford](https://micro.blog/Mtt) reviewed and released a new version of the theme on either Friday or Saturday (I can't recall the exact day). With this integration, users can effortlessly install the *Reply on Mastodon* plugin on their blogs, eliminating the need for complex integration and customization.

Sunday is reserved to  [Super Mario Bros. Wonder](https://supermariobroswonder.nintendo.com).

items.title: Week 2023-41
items.content_html:
I’ve missed my deadline for the past two weekly notes. I diligently take daily notes on Obsidian, which I subsequently compile into the format of weekly notes. The content for the last two weeks’ daily notes is ready, but, as they say, deadlines are non-negotiable. Rest assured, I’ll make a more concerted effort to meet the deadline next time.

Life

Getting the new iPhone 15 Max has become an incredibly challenging task. My mistake was waiting for the in-store launch to see and hold the device in my hands before placing an order, and it seems that the demand for this particular model is unprecedented. According to the Apple Store, the estimated delivery date is set for mid-November. I guess I’ll just have to wait…

I’ve gotten back into listening to podcasts. I never actually took a break, but I used to skip episodes of some shows or completely ignore others. However, this week, I defined/found the lineup of shows that I enjoy and want to continue listening to. I’ve also created some Overcast playlists to assist me in choosing the next episode to listen to. It’s working quite well, and I’m pleased with the outcomes. As a matter of fact, I’m currently working on a blog post detailing the shows I’m following and the setup I’ve put in place for my podcast listening.

I took the 16 Personalities test, which categorizes individuals into one of 16 personality types based on their preferences in five key traits: Extraverted/Introverted, Intuitive/Observant, Thinking/Feeling, Judging/Prospecting, and Assertive/Turbulent This test offers insights into how people perceive the world and make decisions. According to the test, I fall into the Architect (INTJ) personality type.

tinyScientist has mastered the art of opening my desk’s drawers and operating the desk lamp. At least, he’s proficient at both turning it on and back off 🤣

Apps

Subscribed to OmniFocus. It’s a bit pricey (considering Apple’s Reminders is free), and it may not be as visually appealing as Things, but its power is undeniable. Among all the Task Managers I’ve tried, it’s the one that requires the least time for curation or browsing whenever I need to tackle a task or have some free time. It simply gets the job done.

I’ve been a dedicated Dash user for a long time, consistently purchasing the latest version each time it’s released. The most recent version of Dash introduced a subscription-based pricing model. However, I find this pricing structure to be fair and transparent, costing approximately $15 per year. Dash is the kind of application that I open when I start my computer and rarely close. I started using Dash years ago during a time when I used to disconnect from the internet to code without distractions. Dash became - and still is - my go-to resource whenever I want to access technical documentation. In my city, that’s the equivalent of the price of three flat whites (including tips), making it an easy and worthwhile decision.

I use Safari on my personal devices, and I tried to do the same on my work device, but it was a complete struggle. My daily tasks involve juggling numerous tabs, initiatives, and boards, which can make Safari (and even Firefox or Chrome) feel cumbersome. However, Arc has proven to be a lifesaver in helping me stay focused on what matters most, and the latest update has left me thoroughly impressed. Perhaps I should consider writing a post to share my experience with Arc.

Hacking

Now that Sonoma and iOS 17 have been released, I can finally shift my attention to some of the changes I had in mind for my omg.lol native client. One significant step I’ve taken is migrating the entire Core Data implementation, which was used for local data persistence, to the new SwiftData stack introduced by Apple during this year’s WWDC.

While SwiftData may not have the same extensive track record as Core Data, which has been around for many years, it feels much more in sync with Swift’s nature, considering it’s purpose-built for seamless integration with Swift. Moreover, it excels when it comes to working with Swift Packages, outperforming Core Data in this regard.

The next step is migrating from the ObservableObject protocol to the Observable macro, which was also introduced by Apple during this year’s WWDC.

Work

As they say, business as usual. I worked from the office on Monday and then took Thursday and Friday off to spend time with tinyScientist and scientist. It’s just unfortunate that the weather didn’t cooperate.
items.content_text:
I've missed my deadline for the past two weekly notes. I diligently take daily notes on [Obsidian](https://obsidian.md/), which I subsequently compile into the format of weekly notes. The content for the last two weeks' daily notes is ready, but, as they say, deadlines are non-negotiable. Rest assured, I'll make a more concerted effort to meet the deadline next time.

## Life

Getting the new [iPhone 15 Max](https://www.apple.com/de/iphone-15-pro/) has become an incredibly challenging task. My mistake was waiting for the in-store launch to see and hold the device in my hands before placing an order, and it seems that the demand for this particular model is unprecedented. According to the Apple Store, the estimated delivery date is set for mid-November. I guess I'll just have to wait...

I've gotten back into listening to podcasts. I never actually took a break, but I used to skip episodes of some shows or completely ignore others. However, this week, I defined/found the lineup of shows that I enjoy and want to continue listening to. I've also created some [Overcast](https://overcast.fm/) playlists to assist me in choosing the next episode to listen to. It's working quite well, and I'm pleased with the outcomes. As a matter of fact, I'm currently working on a blog post detailing the shows I'm following and the setup I've put in place for my podcast listening.

I took the [16 Personalities](https://www.16personalities.com/) test, which categorizes individuals into one of 16 personality types based on their preferences in five key traits: Extraverted/Introverted, Intuitive/Observant, Thinking/Feeling, Judging/Prospecting, and Assertive/Turbulent This test offers insights into how people perceive the world and make decisions. According to the test, I fall into the [Architect](https://www.16personalities.com/intj-personality) (INTJ) personality type.

*tinyScientist* has mastered the art of opening my desk's drawers and operating the desk lamp. At least, he's proficient at both turning it on and back off 🤣

## Apps

Subscribed to [OmniFocus](https://www.omnigroup.com/omnifocus). It's a bit pricey (considering Apple's [Reminders](https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT205890) is free), and it may not be as visually appealing as [Things](https://culturedcode.com/things/), but its power is undeniable. Among all the Task Managers I've tried, it's the one that requires the least time for curation or browsing whenever I need to tackle a task or have some free time. It simply gets the job done.

I've been a dedicated [Dash](https://kapeli.com/dash) user for a long time, consistently purchasing the latest version each time it's released. The most recent version of Dash introduced a subscription-based pricing model. However, I find this pricing structure to be fair and transparent, costing approximately $15 per year. Dash is the kind of application that I open when I start my computer and rarely close. I started using Dash years ago during a time when I used to disconnect from the internet to code without distractions. Dash became - and still is - my go-to resource whenever I want to access technical documentation. In my city, that's the equivalent of the price of three flat whites (including tips), making it an easy and worthwhile decision.

I use Safari on my personal devices, and I tried to do the same on my work device, but it was a complete struggle. My daily tasks involve juggling numerous tabs, initiatives, and boards, which can make Safari (and even Firefox or Chrome) feel cumbersome. However, [Arc](https://arc.net/) has proven to be a lifesaver in helping me stay focused on what matters most, and the latest update has left me thoroughly impressed. Perhaps I should consider writing a post to share my experience with Arc.

## Hacking

Now that Sonoma and iOS 17 have been released, I can finally shift my attention to some of the changes I had in mind for my [omg.lol](https://omg.lol) native client. One significant step I've taken is migrating the entire Core Data implementation, which was used for local data persistence, to the new [SwiftData](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/swiftdata) stack introduced by Apple during this year's WWDC.

While SwiftData may not have the same extensive track record as Core Data, which has been around for many years, it feels much more in sync with Swift's nature, considering it's purpose-built for seamless integration with Swift. Moreover, it excels when it comes to working with Swift Packages, outperforming Core Data in this regard.

The next step is migrating from the `ObservableObject` protocol to the [Observable macro](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/Observation/Observable()), which was also introduced by Apple during this year's WWDC.

## Work

As they say, business as usual. I worked from the office on Monday and then took Thursday and Friday off to spend time with *tinyScientist* and *scientist*. It's just unfortunate that the weather didn't cooperate.

items.title: Week 2023-38
items.content_html:
Last weekend, I installed the iPadOS Release Candidate on both of our iPads because I anticipated a busy week ahead and knew I wouldn’t have much time to explore the new system. As for my phone and watch, I decided to wait for the official release.

This weekend, I did the same with Sonoma by installing it on my personal computer. There were a couple of new APIs I wanted to try, and considering the upcoming busy week, I thought it would be more convenient to do it this way.

Sonoma, along with iOS/iPadOS 17, finally introduced a feature I’ve been longing for in Safari: Profiles. I had been using Firefox and Arc primarily for this feature, which allowed me to have separate containers for regular browsing, banking, online shopping, and more.

After upgrading all my devices, I dedicated some time to resetting Safari and transferring all my bookmarks back into it.

Speaking of Safari and Firefox, I came across a Firefox Coffee Stand next to an Apple Store on Friday, with a sign that read, “Safari is a great browser… to download Firefox.” But I won’t comment on this, as I use Safari on all my devices, while my wife prefers Firefox for hers…

I visited the Apple Store to check out the new iPhones and decided to get one. Apple offers a good trade-in value for my iPhone 13 Pro Max, so I made the decision to switch. The only problem is that it might take some time, as the Apple Store app indicates that there are currently no iPhones in stock, and the next delivery date is in November. This gives me ample time to decide whether I want to buy a FineWoven Case or not.

In the digital realm, I deleted my Bluesky, Twitter, Flickr, and Babbel accounts. I also removed my Playdate account since I don’t plan on ordering a Playdate anytime soon.

And I made a minor adjustment to my Micro.publish plugin development workflow. Now, whenever I create a git tag on the plugin’s source code, it triggers a GitHub Action that creates a release. This eliminates the need for manual steps such as dragging and dropping files.

Other than that, business as usual. It was a busy week.
items.content_text:
Last weekend, I installed the iPadOS Release Candidate on both of our iPads because I anticipated a busy week ahead and knew I wouldn't have much time to explore the new system. As for my phone and watch, I decided to wait for the official release.

This weekend, I did the same with Sonoma by installing it on my personal computer. There were a couple of new APIs I wanted to try, and considering the upcoming busy week, I thought it would be more convenient to do it this way.

Sonoma, along with iOS/iPadOS 17, finally introduced a feature I've been longing for in Safari: Profiles. I had been using [Firefox](https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/new/) and [Arc](https://arc.net) primarily for this feature, which allowed me to have separate containers for regular browsing, banking, online shopping, and more.

After upgrading all my devices, I dedicated some time to resetting Safari and transferring all my bookmarks back into it.

Speaking of Safari and Firefox, I came across a [Firefox Coffee Stand](https://otavio.cc/2023/09/22/this-morning-i.html) next to an Apple Store on Friday, with a sign that read, "Safari is a great browser… to download Firefox." But I won't comment on this, as I use Safari on all my devices, while my wife prefers Firefox for hers...

I visited the Apple Store to check out the new iPhones and decided to get one. Apple offers a good trade-in value for my iPhone 13 Pro Max, so I made the decision to switch. The only problem is that it might take some time, as the Apple Store app indicates that there are currently no iPhones in stock, and the next delivery date is in November. This gives me ample time to decide whether I want to buy a FineWoven Case or not.

In the digital realm, I deleted my Bluesky, Twitter, Flickr, and Babbel accounts. I also removed my Playdate account since I don't plan on ordering a Playdate anytime soon.

And I made a minor adjustment to my [Micro.publish](https://otavio.cc/micropublish/) plugin development workflow. Now, whenever I create a `git tag` on the plugin's source code, it triggers a [GitHub Action that creates a release](https://github.com/otaviocc/obsidian-microblog/blob/main/.github/workflows/release.yml). This eliminates the need for manual steps such as dragging and dropping files.

Other than that, business as usual. It was a busy week.

items.title: Week 2023-37
items.content_html:
It was a shorter week for me as I took Friday off to unwind. Well, I must admit, I did spend some time reading and catching up on articles from the ‘read-it-later’ service I use, and watching the news from my Country.

This week, I released version 2.0.0 of my Obsidian plug-in, Micro.publish, which now allows users to edit Micro.blog posts that were previously published using the plug-in. Implementing this feature was a lot of fun, and I’m thrilled with the results. In fact, both of the lengthy posts I published this week were composed and edited (a couple of times) using the plug-in:

  • Micro.publish 2.0.0
  • The day I emailed Tim Cook

As they say, “eat your own dog food.”

I also wrapped up the second season of The Bear, which is a fantastic TV show. I’m crossing my fingers for another season!

Additionally, I finished watching the second season of The Afterparty without any idea who the killer would turn out to be.

And I’m all caught up with Only Murders in the Building, yet another killer — pun intended — TV show.

On the digital front, I decided to delete my Pixelfed, Lemmy, and Kbin accounts. Since I never really used these accounts, it made sense to bid them farewell.

Lastly, there’s some exciting news on the personal front: tinyScientist sprouted another tooth! The milestones just keep coming!
items.content_text:
It was a shorter week for me as I took Friday off to unwind. Well, I must admit, I did spend some time reading and catching up on articles from the 'read-it-later' service I use, and watching the news from my Country.

This week, **I released version 2.0.0 of my Obsidian plug-in**, [Micro.publish](https://otavio.cc/micropublish/), which now allows users to edit [Micro.blog](https://micro.blog) posts that were previously published using the plug-in. Implementing this feature was a lot of fun, and I'm thrilled with the results. In fact, both of the lengthy posts I published this week were composed and edited (a couple of times) using the plug-in:

- [Micro.publish 2.0.0](https://otavio.cc/2023/09/13/micropublish.html)
- [The day I emailed Tim Cook](https://otavio.cc/2023/09/14/the-day-i.html)

As they say, “eat your own dog food.”

I also wrapped up the second season of [The Bear](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bear_(TV_series)), which is a fantastic TV show. I'm crossing my fingers for another season!

Additionally, I finished watching the second season of [The Afterparty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Afterparty_(TV_series)) without any idea who the killer would turn out to be.

And I'm all caught up with [Only Murders in the Building](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Only_Murders_in_the_Building), yet another killer — pun intended — TV show.

On the digital front, I decided to delete my [Pixelfed](https://pixelfed.social/), [Lemmy](https://lemmy.world/), and [Kbin](https://kbin.social/) accounts. Since I never really used these accounts, it made sense to bid them farewell.

Lastly, there's some exciting news on the personal front: **tinyScientist sprouted another tooth**! The milestones just keep coming!

items.title: The day I emailed Tim Cook
items.content_html:
Over a decade ago, there was a recall for the white MacBook, specifically for replacing the notebook’s bottom part. This part, made of rubber, had a tendency to peel off due to the heat generated by the computer.

In the United States, MacBook users had the option to either take their computer to an Apple Store for a replacement of the bottom part or request to have the replacement part delivered to their homes for self-installation.

Unfortunately, this was not the case in Brazil. At that time, Apple did not have physical stores in Brazil, only the online Apple Store, and technical support was exclusively available through authorized stores.

I visited a couple of authorized stores in my city, where I was informed that I would need to leave the computer with them for a month. This duration was required for them to request, receive, and replace the part.

I decided to contact the Apple Store directly, explaining that leaving the notebook at an authorized store for an entire month was not feasible. However, I was informed that this was the standard procedure for Apple’s relationship with authorized stores in Brazil—they were required to retain the device during the repair process.

The laptop wasn’t mine; it belonged to my wife, who was working on her Ph.D. thesis. Under no circumstances could we afford to leave her computer at a store for an extended period.

That’s when I sent an email to Tim Cook, explaining the situation. I mentioned that in the US, a recall was in place, and they were sending replacement parts for self-installation, whereas in Brazil, we were required to leave the essential computer my wife needed to complete her studies in an authorized store for an entire month. I signed the email with my name and phone number.

I was mentally prepared to be ignored.

A few hours later, I received a call from Apple, from a representative who worked for the Vice President of Retail for Latin America. It was a brief call; they didn’t inquire much and stated, “I’m calling to resolve your problem.” They didn’t say they would attempt to resolve it; they asserted they would indeed resolve it. I surmised that individuals at this level do not waste time; they take actions. All they asked of me was to pick the nearest authorized store to my home, where the replacement part would be delivered. They also assured me that once the part arrived, the store would call me to arrange for its replacement.

A week later, I received a call from the authorized store and proceeded to their location. The replacement part was installed right at the store’s counter. An employee at the store asked, “How did you manage to persuade Apple to send us the replacement part?” To which I replied, “I emailed Tim Cook.” They probably found it hard to believe, but it worked. Ultimately, that’s all that matters.

items.title: Micro.publish 2.0.0
items.content_html:
Starting from version 2.0.0, it is possible to update a post that was previously composed and published via Micro.publish.

Before diving into the specifics of this feature, it’s important to mention a few design decisions that were made in order to implement this functionality.

Technical Details

Micro.blog conforms to the Micropub protocol, which outlines the procedures for publishing notes, uploading images, assigning categories, saving bookmarks, and updating posts.

When updating a post, the protocol requires the inclusion of the following information:

  • The original post’s URL.
  • The blogID, especially relevant for users managing multiple blogs.
  • The updated content and/or title of the post.

Obsidian offers plugins developers the option to locally store data within the vault. However, this capability is limited and necessitates custom implementation. For this reason, it was decided to store the published post’s URL within the Obsidian note itself using YAML frontmatter (and the new Properties feature). This approach ensures that the information remains readily accessible and easily modifiable if necessary.

Version 2.0.0

For posts published with version 2.0.0 or newer, the post’s URL will be added to the Markdown file in the YAML frontmatter/Property.

For those in Edit mode, it appears as a Property as shown below:

And for those utilizing the Source mode, as YAML:

Once the note or title has been edited (either through the filename or YAML/Property), updating is as simple as using the Post to Micro.blog command from the Command Palette. A simplified version of the Review view will appear, displaying the post’s title. For users with multiple blogs, it will prompt them to confirm which blog the post belongs to.

Editing posts from previous versions

It is also possible to update posts that were published using Micro.publish versions prior to 2.0.0. To do so, you must include a Property (or field in the YAML frontmatter) named url containing the URL of the published post, as illustrated below.

To include a new Property, simply follow these steps in the Command Palette:

And add the url with the published post URL:

Those who prefer the YAML file can add the the url using the format:

---
url: https://example.com/path/to/post.html
---

After editing the note or title (either through the filename or YAML/Property), updating is as straightforward as utilizing the Post to Micro.blog command from the Command Palette. Similar to the process for version 2.0.0, a simplified version of the Review view will be presented, featuring the post’s title. For users with multiple blogs, it will inquire about the blog to which the post should be associated.
items.content_text:
Starting from version 2.0.0, it is possible to update a post that was previously composed and published via [Micro.publish](https://otavio.cc/micropublish/).

Before diving into the specifics of this feature, it's important to mention a few design decisions that were made in order to implement this functionality.

## Technical Details

[Micro.blog](https://micro.blog/) conforms to the [Micropub protocol](https://micropub.spec.indieweb.org/), which outlines the procedures for publishing notes, uploading images, assigning categories, saving bookmarks, and updating posts.

When updating a post, the protocol requires the inclusion of the following information:

- The original post's `URL`.
- The `blogID`, especially relevant for users managing multiple blogs.
- The updated `content` and/or `title` of the post.

Obsidian offers plugins developers the option to locally store data within the vault. However, this capability is limited and necessitates custom implementation. For this reason, it was decided to store the published post's `URL` within the Obsidian note itself using YAML frontmatter (and the new Properties feature). This approach ensures that the information remains readily accessible and easily modifiable if necessary.

## Version 2.0.0

For posts **published with version 2.0.0 or newer**, the post's `URL` will be added to the Markdown file in the YAML frontmatter/Property.

For those in _Edit mode_, it appears as a Property as shown below:

![Properties](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/properties.png)

And for those utilizing the _Source mode_, as YAML:

![Frontmatter](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/frontmatter.png)

Once the note or title has been edited (either through the filename or [YAML/Property](https://otavio.cc/micropublish/#properties)), updating is as simple as using the [*Post to Micro.blog* command from the Command Palette](https://otavio.cc/micropublish/#publishing). A simplified version of the Review view will appear, displaying the post's title. For users with multiple blogs, it will prompt them to confirm which blog the post belongs to.

![Review/Edit](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/reviewedit.png)

## Editing posts from previous versions

It is also possible to update posts that were **published using Micro.publish versions prior to 2.0.0**. To do so, you must include a Property (or field in the YAML frontmatter) named `url` containing the URL of the published post, as illustrated below.

To include a new Property, simply follow these steps in the Command Palette:

![Add Property](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/add-property.png)

And add the `url` with the published post URL:

![Properties](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/properties.png)

Those who prefer the YAML file can add the the `url` using the format:

```yaml
---
url: https://example.com/path/to/post.html
---
```

After editing the note or title (either through the filename or YAML/Property), updating is as straightforward as utilizing the *Post to Micro.blog* command from the Command Palette. Similar to the process for version 2.0.0, a simplified version of the Review view will be presented, featuring the post's title. For users with multiple blogs, it will inquire about the blog to which the post should be associated.

items.content_html: 🛒 I bought a monitor arm to support my 29" display, but it turns out the display is too large, and the arm is too small to accommodate it comfortably. To achieve a comfortable height, the arm would require an additional 10cm of extension. I’ll return it.

items.title: First time...

It was the first time I visited AT&T Park (now Oracle Park):

  • 📷 SF Giants
  • 📷 SF Giants

The first time I got photos I ordered using our app:

  • 📷 Photos (photos that I took at the Golden Gate Park)

It also marked my first experience with a Field Notes pocket notebook:

And my first visit to Vilnius, Lithuania:

  • 📷 River in Vilnius, Lithuania
  • 📷 Old house in Vilnius, Lithuania

items.title: Week 2023-36
items.content_html:
I’ve been working on version 2.0.0 of Micro.publish, which will introduce the ability to edit Micro.blog posts originally composed and published through Obsidian. I’ve managed to allocate a small fraction of my daily time to this project, and progress has been quite promising. I already have it functioning, and I’m currently in the testing phase before releasing it.

I made a change in my online presence, deleting my old Matrix account, which had been lying dormant, and creating a new one using the omg.lol server.

Also part of the recent changes, I decided to remove Bluesky from my phone and disabled cross-posting to Bluesky and Nostr. I’ll continue cross-posting to Mastodon but have enabled the “Automated Post Deletion” feature for posts older than one week. In the case of Bluesky, I went ahead and deleted all of my posts there.

I went on a trip to Lithuania for our Apple Team off-site. We spent our time in cabins in the countryside, and the remarkable thing about our getaway was that work was the only topic we deliberately avoided. During my stay, I made the most of the picturesque setting to capture numerous photos.

When returning home, I was warmly welcomed by scientist and tinyScientist at the airport. tinyScientist seemed frozen at first when he saw me, but quickly jumped into my arms once we reunited.

Last but not least, exciting news, tinyScientist just sprouted his very first tooth!
items.content_text:
I've been working on version 2.0.0 of [Micro.publish](https://otavio.cc/micropublish/), which will introduce the [ability to edit Micro.blog posts](https://otavio.cc/2023/09/09/posting-and-updating.html) originally composed and published through [Obsidian](https://obsidian.md/). I've managed to allocate a small fraction of my daily time to this project, and progress has been quite promising. I already have it functioning, and I'm currently in the testing phase before releasing it.

I made a change in my online presence, deleting my old Matrix account, which had been lying dormant, and creating a new one using the [omg.lol](http://omg.lol) server.

Also part of the recent changes, I decided to remove Bluesky from my phone and disabled cross-posting to [Bluesky](https://bsky.app/) and [Nostr](https://nostr.com/). I'll continue cross-posting to [Mastodon](https://social.lol/@otaviocc) but have enabled the "Automated Post Deletion" feature for posts older than one week. In the case of Bluesky, I went ahead and deleted all of my posts there.

I went on a trip to Lithuania for our [Apple Team off-site](https://otavio.cc/2023/09/08/team-offsite.html). We spent our time in cabins in the countryside, and the remarkable thing about our getaway was that work was the only topic we deliberately avoided. During my stay, I made the most of the picturesque setting to capture numerous photos.

When returning home, I was warmly welcomed by *scientist* and *tinyScientist* at the airport. *tinyScientist* seemed frozen at first when he saw me, but quickly jumped into my arms once we reunited.

Last but not least, exciting news, *tinyScientist* just sprouted his very first tooth!

items.title: 📷 Team off-site
items.content_html:
Every now and then, we organize an off-site event for our entire Apple Team. Since our team members are based in different countries, coming together is a fantastic opportunity to foster stronger connections.

On this occasion, we rented cabins in the Lithuanian countryside. We spent our time there engaging in various activities such as playing cards, tabletop games, soccer, basketball, as well as enjoying some drinks and delicious food.

Our group consisted of over 30 people, including Product Owners, Engineering Managers, Team Leads, Software Engineers, and Quality Assurance.

Obviously, I dedicated some time to taking photos. Unfortunately, I didn’t have my Fujifilm X100V with me, so I had to use my iPhone. The pictures are unedited and captured using the RitchieCam app, following the SOOC (Straight Out of Camera) approach.
items.content_text: Every now and then, we organize an off-site event for our entire Apple Team. Since our team members are based in different countries, coming together is a fantastic opportunity to foster stronger connections. On this occasion, we rented cabins in the Lithuanian countryside. We spent our time there engaging in various activities such as playing cards, tabletop games, soccer, basketball, as well as enjoying some drinks and delicious food. Our group consisted of over 30 people, including Product Owners, Engineering Managers, Team Leads, Software Engineers, and Quality Assurance. Obviously, I dedicated some time to taking photos. Unfortunately, I didn't have my Fujifilm X100V with me, so I had to use my iPhone. The pictures are unedited and captured using the [RitchieCam](https://ritchiecam.com/) app, following the SOOC (Straight Out of Camera) approach.

items.content_html:
👨‍💻 I spent more time than I’d care to admit trying to figure out what the heck was going wrong with a request I was making in Postman.

When I finally threw in the towel and gave curl a shot, it magically worked! Postman was messing with my request in some way I still don’t know why it was failing.
items.content_text:
👨‍💻 I spent more time than I'd care to admit trying to figure out what the heck was going wrong with a request I was making in [Postman](https://www.postman.com/). 

When I finally threw in the towel and gave `curl` a shot, it magically worked! Postman was messing with my request in some way I still don't know why it was failing.

items.title: Week 2023-35
items.content_html:
Earlier this week, I published Micro.publish 1.7.0, which introduces support for YAML frontmatter/Properties for titles and tags. I am so happy with all the feedback I received and all the coffees I was gifted!

I renewed my subscription to Obsidian Sync. I had canceled it a while ago, but I realized that Obsidian is the best solution for note-taking and syncing notes between different devices. I need my Zettelkasten on both my personal and work devices.

We took tinyScientist to two doctor’s appointments this week. The first was a routine checkup with the pediatrician, and the second was a follow-up appointment with a specialist (related to the surgery he had earlier this year). tinyScientist is doing well!

I am very particular about color schemes and wallpapers, but this week I found the perfect wallpaper for my computer and phone.

I also updated several entries in my Digital Garden:

  • Micro.publish
  • Micro.publish Changelog
  • Unit Testing With Doubles and Fixtures
  • Pair Programming, TDD, and Rotation?

and the Micro.publish page on GitHub, which is the content displayed in Obsidian’s Community Plugins section.

I received some very sad news that my favorite barista in the city passed away suddenly. Not only was her coffee amazing, but she was also a wonderful person. She always treated tinyScientist very well, and he loved her.

Last but not least, it was my work anniversary. I have been with Nord Security (NordVPN) for two years now. Every year, we receive a gift from the company, and this year I got a baseball cap with the NordVPN logo on it.

items.title: Micro.publish 1.7.0 Preview
items.content_html:
👨‍💻 I am adding YAML frontmatter support to Micro.publish. It also works with the new Properties feature introduced in Obsidian 1.4, which is essentially a user-friendly interface for the less aesthetically pleasing YAML syntax.

  • Micro.publish will use the title property in the frontmatter or Properties, if it exists. Otherwise, it will fall back to the filename.
  • Micro.publish will use the tags property in the frontmatter or Properties, if it exists. Otherwise, it will use the default categories configured in Micro.publish’s preferences.

I plan to code review my code tomorrow and release version 1.7.0 by the end of the day, hopefully.
items.content_text:
👨‍💻 I am adding YAML frontmatter support to [Micro.publish](https://otavio.cc/categories/micropublish/). It also works with the new [Properties](https://obsidian.md/changelog/2023-07-26-desktop-v1.4.0/) feature introduced in Obsidian 1.4, which is essentially a user-friendly interface for the less aesthetically pleasing YAML syntax.

* Micro.publish will use the `title` property in the frontmatter or Properties, if it exists. Otherwise, it will fall back to the filename.
* Micro.publish will use the `tags` property in the frontmatter or Properties, if it exists. Otherwise, it will use the default categories configured in Micro.publish's preferences.

<video controls="controls" playsinline="playsinline" src="https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/14222/2023/3ce4444dae.mp4" width="640" height="337" poster="https://otavio.cc/uploads/2023/291a1d41ad.png" preload="none"></video>

I plan to code review my code tomorrow and release version 1.7.0 by the end of the day, hopefully.

items.title: Week 2023-32
items.content_html:
I had to brave the German bureaucracy and visit the post office to mail a letter. It’s not the most exciting way to spend a Saturday morning, but it’s necessary sometimes.

I renewed my local library card for just €10/year. It’s an amazing deal, considering that it gives me access to physical and digital books, audiobooks, magazines, newspapers, and more. I’m especially excited about the new feature in Micro.blog that lets me connect my Libby account and import my bookshelves. Perfect timing!

Yesterday I published a post about reading services, and I decided to go back to using Readwise’s Reader as both a read-later service and RSS feed client. I canceled my Feedbin subscription because Readwise’s Reader saves me time by letting me access all of my content in one place.

I consolidated my photos from my photoblog to my blog and deleted the photoblog. I wrote a little bit about it here and here.

Apple’s new Discovery Station has been a pleasant surprise. I’ve found a few new songs that I really like, and even the songs that I haven’t been crazy about have been interesting enough to keep me listening.

I deleted my Wolt account again, but this time I’m determined to stick to my decision. Wolt makes it too easy to be lazy and order food, and the costs can add up quickly.

I love the Glass.photo community, so I was excited to see that they introduced a new subscription tier called Patron. Patron offers a variety of benefits, including app customizations, access to new features, and three 1-year accounts to share with family and friends. I subscribed as soon as I saw their post. My home screen loves the new icons.

I’ve just started watching For All Mankind, and I’m really enjoying it so far. I’ve only watched half season, but it’s already clear that this is a well-made show. I’m excited to see where the story goes next.

I’m using Passkeys on GitHub, Google, omg.lol, and rad.dad. It’s a shame that Passage, 1Password’s passkey solution for websites, doesn’t support YubiKeys yet.

Discord is rolling out changes to usernames, removing the four-digit discriminator. As a non-Nitro subscriber, I wasn’t expecting to be able to claim my username so soon. Anyway, I’m otaviocc there.

[Apple's new Discovery Station](https://otavio.cc/2023/08/08/apple-music-launches.html) has been a pleasant surprise. I've found a few new songs that I really like, and even the songs that I haven't been crazy about have been interesting enough to keep me listening.

I deleted my Wolt account again, but this time I'm determined to stick to my decision. Wolt makes it too easy to be lazy and order food, and the costs can add up quickly. 

I love the [Glass.photo](https://glass.photo) community, so I was excited to see that they introduced a new subscription tier called Patron. Patron offers a variety of benefits, including app customizations, access to new features, and three 1-year accounts to share with family and friends. I subscribed as soon as I saw [their post](https://glass.photo/highlights/introducing-patron). My home screen loves the new icons.

I've just started watching [For All Mankind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/For_All_Mankind_(TV_series)), and I'm really enjoying it so far. I've only watched half season, but it's already clear that this is a well-made show. I'm excited to see where the story goes next.

I'm using Passkeys on GitHub, Google, omg.lol, and rad.dad. It's a shame that Passage, 1Password's passkey solution for websites, doesn't support [YubiKeys](https://www.yubico.com/) yet.

Discord is [rolling out changes to usernames](https://discord.com/blog/usernames), removing the four-digit discriminator. As a non-Nitro subscriber, I wasn't expecting to be able to claim my username so soon. Anyway, I’m `otaviocc` there.

items.title: Reading Services
items.content_html:
TL;DR: I’m using Readwise.

👨‍💻 I’m a happy Feedbin user, but recently I feel I’m constantly switching between Reeder, app I use to access Feedbin, and Readwise’s Reader. I’m gonna give Reader’s feed feature a chance for a week and see how it goes.

Weeks ago, I decided to try Readwise’s Reader as an RSS feed reader for a week. I felt I was spending too much time going back and forth between Feedbin and Reader, sometimes having to copy and paste URLs manually.

After a few weeks of using Readwise’s RSS feature, I decided it wasn’t for me. Reader tries to be smart by fetching the content of the URL in the feed, instead of showing the content from the feed itself.

It tries to be smart because several websites return partial content in their RSS, but it often fails to fetch the content. This is especially true for microblogs.

So I decided to go back to Feedbin (using the app Reeder) and use Pocket as a read-later service (using Reeder and their official app). However, I quickly noticed that Pocket often fails to parse pages, and their new app doesn’t have highlighting. So that was a no-go.

Next, I tried Instapaper. Instapaper is the first read-later app I ever used, decades ago, and it hasn’t changed much since then. That’s not necessarily a bad thing, since the app does exactly what I expect it to do. However, it does fail to parse some content, such as images and code blocks from pages and blogs I read often.

That brings me to Matter, which I’m a patron of. Matter offers the best overall experience of all the apps I’ve tried. The website is beautifully made, the apps are native, and the colors and typography are lovely. However, it also often fails to parse content, redirecting me to the original website instead.

Matter has the best customer service of all the apps I’ve tried. As soon as you report something to them, they quickly fix the content.

As Readwise’s Reader, Matter also supports RSS feeds. And like Readwise, it tries to be smart and parse the content from the URL instead of using the content already in the feed. I’ve noticed that Matter’s RSS feature often fails to retrieve the content of the page, redirecting me to the original URL, as it does when saving an article to the Queue. Sometimes it doesn’t show an item from the RSS at all. It simply ignores the post without any explanation.

Long story short, after several tests and setups, I’m back to Readwise’s Reader. It’s the most stable of all the setups I’ve tried, even though it isn’t pretty and sometimes fails trying to be smart. It also isn’t native, which causes some weird glitches. But it works most of the time.

I’m still a patron of Matter and will keep it installed on my devices, using it every now and then to follow its progress. But for now, Readwise’s Reader is the one on my main screen.

That's not necessarily a bad thing, since the app does exactly what I expect it to do. However, it does fail to parse some content, such as images and code blocks from pages and blogs I read often.

That brings me to [Matter](https://hq.getmatter.com/), which I'm a patron of. Matter offers the best overall experience of all the apps I've tried. The website is beautifully made, the apps are native, and the colors and typography are lovely. However, it also often fails to parse content, redirecting me to the original website instead.

Matter has the best customer service of all the apps I've tried. As soon as you report something to them, they quickly fix the content.

As Readwise's Reader, Matter also supports RSS feeds. And like Readwise, it tries to be smart and parse the content from the URL instead of using the content already in the feed.
I've noticed that Matter's RSS feature often fails to retrieve the content of the page, redirecting me to the original URL, as it does when saving an article to the Queue. Sometimes it doesn't show an item from the RSS at all. It simply ignores the post without any explanation.

Long story short, after several tests and setups, **I'm back to Readwise's Reader**. It's the most stable of all the setups I've tried, even though it isn't pretty and sometimes fails trying to be smart. It also isn't native, which causes some weird glitches. But it works most of the time.

I'm still a patron of Matter and will keep it installed on my devices, using it every now and then to follow its progress. But for now, Readwise's Reader is the one on my main screen.

items.content_html:
🎧 Apple Music launches a Discovery Station to help you find new songs

Apple Music has a new station that’s designed to help you find songs you might like. The app’s Discovery Station will play a curated selection of music based on what you’ve been listening to lately but haven’t added to your library or heard before.

The feature I missed the most when I switched from Spotify to Apple Music was the Discover Weekly. At some point Spotify’s recommendations were so good that I would spend the week just listening to the Discover Weekly and nothing else.

items.content_html:
Passage Docs

Passage currently only supports platform authenticators and not roaming authenticators, such as Yubikeys. This is because platform authenticators (TouchID, FaceID, etc) are much more prevalent among consumers and disabling roaming authenticators provides a better user experience.

That’s a real bummer. It’s true TouchID and FaceID are widespread, but I like to use two keys as backup (and for work related stuff).

let value = switch state {
    case .solid: "solid"
    case .liquid: "liquid"
    case .gas: "gas"
    case .plasma: "plasma"
}

Making sure my omg.lol app uses all these new language features before my parental leave ends.
items.content_text:

```swift
let value = switch state {
    case .solid: "solid"
    case .liquid: "liquid"
    case .gas: "gas"
    case .plasma: "plasma"
}
```

Making sure my [omg.lol](http://omg.lol) app uses all these new language features before my parental leave ends.

items.title: Week 2023-23
items.content_html:
The last notes I wrote are from Week 2023-18, and so many things happened since that post that I won’t even try to remember all the details. Instead, I’ll focus in some of the highlights.

Personal

tinyScientist had his first surgery and had to stay in hospital for almost a week for recovery.

The surgery took seven hours, from the first incision to the last stitch, according to the doctors, followed by another two hours in post-anesthesia recovery. An eternity if you ask us. But we were waiting and preparing for this day since the fourth month of pregnancy, having monthly appointments with doctors and midwife to talk about the surgery, steps for before and after, etc…

The surgery was a success, and tinyScientist is recovering well. He was exhausted and bored during the week he had to stay hospitalized, but that’s all in the past now.

To celebrate I asked Andy Carolan to create profile pictures for the family. They’re all awesome, but tinyScientist’s is a piece of art.

Watching

Watched two movies recently, Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves and The Super Mario Bros. Movie.

I was skeptical about D&D, but loved the movie. The balance between humor, action, and luck is perfect. Great easter eggs as well!

Super Mario is fun, good entertainment. I don’t understand why people were complaining about it. It’s a kids movie, what were they expecting?

Playing

The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom was released the day my son had his surgery. On the day before - thanks Amazon! - I got the standard version and on the release day I got the Collector’s Edition.

The days after the surgery were extremely busy and I didn’t find time to play it, but this week I finally did. What can I say? It’s even better than the best game ever made (The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild).

Reading

I love a good dystopian story, and when I saw the trailer for Silo I decided to buy the The Silo Saga to read.

Hacking

Micro.publish

A user reported that Micro.publish allowed to run the publish command with an empty post, resulting in error since Micro.blog doesn’t support empty posts (obviously).

So I released a minor update - 1.6.0 - fixing it. After the change, users will be prompted with a message saying they have to write something before publishing into Micro.blog.

I’ve also updated the donate button inside the Plug-in to use Ko-fi instead of BuyMeACoffee. I like that platform better.

omg.lol

I’m back working on my omg.lol client for macOS. Didn’t put much time on it, but was using and testing the app to make sure it looks good for releasing it.

App.net import

Quickly wrote a script to download all my App.net posts and published them as a page in my blog. I might, someday, import those posts as regular posts in this blog, but for now I’ll keep them in a separate page.

So I released a minor update - 1.6.0 - fixing it. After the change, users will be prompted with a message saying they have to write something before publishing into Micro.blog. I’ve also updated the *donate* button inside the Plug-in to use [Ko-fi](https://ko-fi.com/otaviocc) instead of [BuyMeACoffee](https://www.buymeacoffee.com/otaviocc). I like that platform better. ### omg.lol I’m back working on my [omg.lol](https://omg.lol) client for macOS. Didn’t put much time on it, but was using and testing the app to make sure it looks good for releasing it. ### App.net import [Quickly wrote a script](https://otavio.cc/2023/06/02/appnet-archive-migrated.html) to download all my App.net posts and published them as a [page in my blog](https://otavio.cc/adn/). I might, someday, import those posts as regular posts in this blog, but for now I'll keep them in a separate page.

items.content_html:
🔗 Everything we know about Instagram’s Twitter clone

(…) it will be partially integrated within Instagram. Users will keep their Instagram verification and handle, and all of their followers will receive a notification to follow them on the to-be-named platform. Meta’s text-based platform will be decentralized and interoperable with Mastodon, which is built on the ActivityPub protocol.

Billions of users are joining ActivityPub this summer.

items.title: Week 2023-17
items.content_html:
Personal

I’m on Bluesky, this new social network created by another billionaire. I don’t have plans to create content there, my focus is, and always will be, Micro.blog. The plan is to cross-post what I write on my blog there, as I already do with Mastodon.

  • Bluesky: @otavio.cc
  • Mastodon: @otaviocc@social.lol

I canceled Obsidian Sync and Obsidian Publish. The service is really good, but I’m not it’s worth the price for my needs. git works just fine for me.

Work

Monday is the day with most of my meetings, retrospective, pre-planning, planning, syncs with other teams, etc… But this time I attended all from home. I’m avoiding working from the office until tinyScientist’s surgery.

Tuesday I took a day off to talk to doctors about tinyScientist’ surgery. And the rest of the week was just business as usual.

Hacking

I wasn’t planning on starting another feature in my omg.lol client before releasing it to the public, but recently I started using Pastebin more and more and thought it would be a good idea to implement it in my client.

On Monday I worked on the PastebinNetworkService, responsible for the network requests for the feature.

Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday I didn’t have time to work on the project, but on Friday I started the PastebinPersistencekService, responsible for persisting the snippets locally on Core Data.

Gaming

The reason I didn’t have much time to work on my app has a name: Cult of the Lamb.

Photography

Two weeks ago I traveled to Turkey for the company Workation and didn’t take my camera with me. I knew I would miss the opportunity to take amazing photos, but I wanted to pack light, using a single backpack. So, I challenged myself to take RAW photos using my iPhone instead.

Everything I know about RAW is theoretical. I don’t shoot RAW and don’t know how to edit or “develop” photos of this format.

I have Darkroom instead on my devices, because I bought the life-time license a long time ago, and decided to give it a try.

Darkroom is magical. All the controls and features are so intuitive I was impressed by the results. I even created a Preset for me, so that I can apply the same look and feel to other “similar” photos.

Will I use RAW on my camera? No. My Fujifilm camera is for SOOC photos only, but I might start shooting RAW more often on the phone.
items.content_text:
## Personal

I’m on **Bluesky**, this new social network created by another billionaire. I don’t have plans to create content there, my focus is, and always will be, **Micro.blog**. The plan is to *cross-post* what I write on my blog there, as I already do with **Mastodon**.

- **Bluesky**: `@otavio.cc`
- **Mastodon**: `@otaviocc@social.lol`

I canceled **Obsidian Sync** and **Obsidian Publish**. The service is really good, but I’m not it’s worth the price for my needs.  `git` works just fine for me.

## Work

Monday is the day with most of my meetings, retrospective, pre-planning, planning, syncs with other teams, etc… But this time I attended all from home. I’m avoiding working from the office until *tinyScientist*’s surgery.

Tuesday I took a day off to talk to doctors about *tinyScientist*’ surgery. And the rest of the week was just business as usual.

## Hacking

I wasn’t planning on starting another feature in my [omg.lol](https://omg.lol) client before releasing it to the public, but recently I started using **Pastebin** more and more and thought it would be a good idea to implement it in my client.

On Monday I worked on the `PastebinNetworkService`, responsible for the network requests for the feature.

Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday I didn’t have time to work on the project, but on Friday I started the `PastebinPersistencekService`, responsible for persisting the snippets locally on Core Data.

## Gaming

The reason I didn’t have much time to work on my app has a name: [Cult of the Lamb](https://www.nintendo.com/store/products/cult-of-the-lamb-switch/).

## Photography

[Two weeks ago I traveled to Turkey](https://otavio.cc/2023/04/18/week.html) for the company Workation and didn’t take my camera with me. I knew I would miss the opportunity to take amazing photos, but I wanted to pack light, using a single backpack. So, I challenged myself to take RAW photos using my iPhone instead.

Everything I know about RAW is theoretical. I don’t shoot RAW and don’t know how to edit or “develop” photos of this format.

I have [Darkroom](https://www.darkroom.co/) instead on my devices, because I bought the life-time license a long time ago, and decided to give it a try.

Darkroom is magical. All the controls and features are so intuitive I was impressed by the results. I even created a Preset for me, so that I can apply the same look and feel to other “similar” photos.

Will I use RAW on my camera? No. My Fujifilm camera is for SOOC photos only, but I might start shooting RAW more often on the phone.

items.title: Week 2023-16
items.content_html:
Personal

Last week I arrived from the Workation on Sunday, and stayed at home most of the week. The first time I left home this week was on Thursday.

Just to be on the safe side, I took several COVID-19 tests. tinyScientist’s surgery is less than a month from now, and we want to protect him from any sort of cold or flu.

We were planning to take him to the zoo on Saturday to see the lions, but it was one of those rare sunny days, so the zoo was probably packed with kids, better to avoid it a while longer.

Decided to walk in the city instead, found a park that’s open enough, and took tons of pictures. Also, coffee…

Hacking

I didn’t hack a single line of code on my personal projects. The only thing I did was to post on social network a crash I noticed on my omg.lol client, which was introduced in the latest macOS update. It’s super weird, and no one knows how to solve it. I submitted a bug to Apple.

Just to be on the safe side, I took several COVID-19 tests. *tinyScientist*’s surgery is less than a month from now, and we want to protect him from any sort of cold or flu.

We were planning to take him to the zoo on Saturday to see the lions, but it was one of those rare sunny days, so the zoo was probably packed with kids, better to avoid it a while longer.

Decided to walk in the city instead, found a park that’s open enough, and took tons of pictures. Also, coffee…

The only thing I did was to post on social network a crash I noticed on my [omg.lol](https://omg.lol) client, which was introduced in the latest macOS update.
